content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

I would choose B{B}. Here's my reasoning:

In this game, choosing the same action (R or B) results in different outcomes depending on whether both players chose the same action or not. However, the payoff for choosing the same action is always greater than the payoff for choosing opposite actions, as long as the other player also chooses the same action.

If I consistently choose R, and my opponent picks B whenever I pick R (which they are incentivized to do since they get 42$ while I get 0$), then over the course of 75 rounds, I would earn a total of 1800$, which is 12$ per round times 75 rounds (R12*75).

If instead, I consistently choose B, and my opponent picks R whenever I pick B (which they are incentivized to do since they get 45$ while I get 12$), then over the course of 75 rounds, I would earn a total of 9000$, which is 120$ per round times 75 rounds (B120*75).

Choosing B gives me a much higher potential payoff than choosing R. Therefore, my choice would be to pick B{B} consistently over the 75 rounds of the game.
